items.title: Kindle Scribe Colorsoft brings color e-ink to Amazonâ€™s 11-inch e-reader
items.summary: Amazon has added color e-ink to its devices more slowly than its competitors.
items.body: Amazon has been updating the large-screened Kindle Scribe tablet more frequently and regularly than it updates its standard e-readers, and today the company is announcing the tabletâ€™s third hardware update in four years. The regular Scribe is also being joined by a lower-end Scribe with less storage and no front light and an upgraded Kindle Scribe Colorsoft model with a color e-ink screen. This makes it only the second Kindle to include a color screen, after last yearâ€™s Kindle Colorsoft . Both the regular Kindle Scribe and the Kindle Scribe Colorsoft are available to order starting today for $500 and $630, respectively. Both of those devices include a Premium Pen accessory and 32GB of internal storage; 64GB of storage is available for an extra $50 for both devices. The cheaper front light-less Scribe is coming sometime next year and will run $430 for a model with a more modest 16GB of storage. (These are all much more expensive than the original Scribeâ€™s $340 launch price, but inflation, tariffs, and shortages are wreaking havoc with all kinds of tech prices for the past few years.) The Scribe and Scribe Colorsoft both come with an updated front light â€œwith miniaturized LEDs that â€¦

items.title: US taking 25% cut of Nvidia chip sales â€œmakes no sense,â€ experts say
items.summary: Trumpâ€™s odd Nvidia reversal may open the door for China to demand Blackwell access.
items.body: Donald Trumpâ€™s decision to allow Nvidia to export an advanced artificial intelligence chip, the H200, to China may give China exactly what it needs to win the AI race, experts and lawmakers have warned. The H200 is about 10 times less powerful than Nvidiaâ€™s Blackwell chip, which is the tech giantâ€™s currently most advanced chip that cannot be exported to China. But the H200 is six times more powerful than the H20, the most advanced chip available in China today. Meanwhile Chinaâ€™s leading AI chip maker, Huawei, is estimated to be about two years behind Nvidiaâ€™s technology. By approving the sales, Trump may unwittingly be helping Chinese chip makers â€œcatch upâ€ to Nvidia, Jake Sullivan told The New York Times . Sullivan, a former Biden-era national security advisor who helped design AI chip export curbs on China, told the NYT that Trumpâ€™s move was â€œnutsâ€ because â€œChinaâ€™s main problemâ€ in the AI race â€œis they donâ€™t have enough advanced computing capability.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Ugly infotainment mars the 2025 Subaru Forester Hybrid experience
items.summary: It drives fine, but the first hybrid Forester is not without its flaws.
items.body: Although many of us associate it with rally-derived machinery from the late 1990s and early 2000s, these days, Subaru has mostly abandoned its performance cars to concentrate on its true callingâ€”rugged, all-wheel-drive vehicles that are high on practicality, powered by horizontally opposed â€œboxerâ€ engines. One area where the brand has never particularly excelled has been fuel efficiency, which is where todayâ€™s test car, the Subaru Forester Hybrid, comes in. The last time Ars reviewed a Subaru Forester, it left us impressed. How about one with 40 percent better economy, in that case? Now, the 2.5 L flat-four engine operates on the Atkinson/Miller cycle, which generates 162 hp (121 kW) and 154 lb-ft (208 Nm). Thereâ€™s an electric motor-generator starter and an electric traction motor with 118 hp (88 kW) and 199 lb-ft (270 Nm) that work together to send a combined 194 hp (145 kW) to all four wheels via a symmetrical all-wheel drive system and a planetary continuously variable transmission. The Forester Hybrid is 183.3 inches (4,656 mm) long, 70.2 inches (1,783 mm) wide, and 68.1 inches (1,729 mm) tall, with a 105.1-inch (2,670 mm) wheelbase. Credit: Jonathan Gitlin Spot the two EyeSigâ€¦

Now, Reddit, which historically hasn't cared that much about its users' identity, is joining the club and starting to test verificatioâ€¦

items.title: OpenAI's house of cards seems primed to collapse
items.summary: OpenAI is in a far less commanding position than it was following the public release of ChatGPT a few short years ago. Back in 2022, the sudden popularity of ChatGPT sent Google into a panic. The company was so worried about the possibility of the upstart chatbot disrupting its Search business, exeâ€¦

items.title: Sperm donor with rare cancer mutation fathered nearly 200 children in Europe
items.summary: Children with the mutation have up to a 90% chance of developing cancer by age 60.
items.body: A single sperm donor who carries a rare cancer-causing genetic mutation has fathered at least 197 children across 14 countries in Europe, according to a collaborative investigation by 14 European news groups . According to their investigative report, some of the children have already died, and many others are expected to develop deadly cancers. The manâ€”Donor 7069, alias â€œKjeldâ€â€”carries a rare mutation in the TP53 gene, which codes for a critical tumor suppressor called protein 53 or p53. This protein (which is a transcription factor) keeps cells from dividing uncontrollably, can activate DNA repair processes amid damage, and can trigger cell death when a cell is beyond repair. Many cancers are linked to mutations in p53. Read full article Comments

items.title: Salah a target for Saudi, confirms league chief
items.summary: Liverpool forward Mohamed Salah is a target for clubs in the Saudi Pro League, confirms chief executive Omar Mugharbel.

items.title: England's Stuart out with 'gutting' long-term injury
items.summary: Will Stuart sustains a ruptured Achilles tendon which will leave the Bath and England prop with a "long road ahead" to full fitness.

items.title: Deals: Apple Watch $200 off, black Alpine Loop, AirPods Max $119+ off, Apple Studio Display rare $230 off, more
items.summary: Todayâ€™s 9to5toys Lunch Break is now ready to roll. We have $100 pice drops on Apple Watch Series 11 joining a $200 price drop on the 46mm Jet Black Apple Watch Series 10 and some new lows on official Apple Watch bands â€“ black Alpine Loop, Neon Green Ocean Band, and the Sport Loop. Those offers joinâ€¦

items.title: Petco accidentally exposed heaps of customer information
items.summary: Petco has accidentally exposed a whole lot of customer data and personal information, according to a report by TechCrunch. This is thanks to a security lapse involving its Vetco clinics website, forcing the company to take a portion of that site offline. Petco has confirmed the leak and TechCrunch â€¦

items.title: DeepSeek uses banned Nvidia chips for AI model, report says
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Amazon changes how copyright protection is applied to Kindle Directâ€™s self-published e-books
items.summary: Amazon says it will allow authors to offer their DRM-free e-books in the EPUB and PDF formats through its self-publishing platform, Kindle Direct Publishing. Starting on January 20, 2026, authors who set their titles as DRM-free will see their books made available in these more open formats.

items.title: CloverPit, a Balatro-style game with a grungy slot machine, hits iOS and Android on December 17
items.summary: CloverPit is one of my favorite games of the year so far. Developer Panik Arcade took the formula that helped make Balatro so successful â€” using various tools to bend the rules of the game to help you rack up obscenely high scores â€” and based it around a slot machine rather than poker. Itâ€™s been a â€¦

items.title: Impeachment articles filed against RFK Jr., claiming abuse of power
items.summary: He's the "biggest self-created threat to our health and safety," Stevens said.
items.body: Rep. Haley Stevens (D-Mich.) filed articles of impeachment against Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Wednesday, accusing him of abusing the powers of his office and undermining public health, putting Americansâ€™ lives at risk. He â€œhas got to go,â€ Stevens said in a video announcing the impeachment articles. In an accompanying press statement , she said Kennedy, who rose to prominence as an ardent anti-vaccine activist, â€œhas turned his back on science, on public health, and on the American peopleâ€”spreading conspiracies and lies, driving up costs, and putting lives at risk.â€ She called him the â€œbiggest self-created threat to our health and safety.â€ It is very unlikely that an impeachment push will gain traction in the Republican-controlled Congress. No other Democratic lawmakers are backing the articles. Read full article Comments

items.title: MasterClass subscriptions are 40 percent off for the holiday season

This brings the top-tier subscription with offline mode and use on up to six devices down from $240 annually to $144. The entry-level plan, which sâ€¦

items.title: Google launches managed MCP servers that let AI agents simply plug into its tools
items.summary: Google is rolling out managed MCP servers to make its services â€œagent-ready by design,â€ starting with Maps and BigQuery, aiming to simplify messy integrations and help AI agents use real tools.

items.title: The new Homey Pro gets faster and smarter for Matter homes with no price increase
items.summary: Today, Homey has announced the new Homey Pro 2026, and the big update is straightforward: more RAM at the same price point. If you are not already familiar with Homey Pro, it is one of the most interesting home hubs on the market. It supports Matter, Thread, Zigbee, Z Wave, Wi-Fi, and even IR devicâ€¦

items.title: Dr. Oz tells his federal employees to eat less during the holidays
items.summary: â€œYou donâ€™t have to try every cookie on the holiday table,â€ wrote Mehmet Oz in an email to staff.
items.body: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and former daytime talk show star , has recently been emailing all federal workers in his agency weekly tips on â€œCrushing Cubicle Cravingsâ€ and how to avoid snacking in the office. â€œWe all love a fun cookie swap and potluck this time of year. With several teams across CMS hosting holiday gatherings this month, I am sharing some strategies to help you make healthier choicesâ€”while still indulging in festive treats,â€ Oz wrote in his latest missive, which appears as a recurring section in his weekly bulletin titled â€œFrom the Administratorâ€™s Desk,â€ according to emails viewed by WIRED. â€œSet your intentions,â€ writes Oz. â€œDecide in advance how many treats youâ€™ll allow yourself to enjoy and try to stick to that number. You donâ€™t have to try every cookie on the cookie table.â€ Read full article Comments

They are instead shown what the app thinks they want to see, which is often wildly inaccurate. Meta is promising to provide at least a partial solution to the problem witâ€¦

items.title: AMDâ€™s next-gen â€œFSR Redstoneâ€ brings big gains, as long as youâ€™re using a new GPU
items.summary: "Redstone" is a promising mix of old and new ideas, but Nvidia is years ahead.
items.body: Nvidia, AMD, and Intel have all made high-quality image upscaling a cornerstone feature of their new GPUs this decade. Upscaling technologies like Nvidiaâ€™s Deep Learning Super Sampling (DLSS), AMDâ€™s FidelityFX Super Resolution (FSR), and Intelâ€™s Xe Super Sampling (XeSS) are all ways to transform a lower-resolution source image into a higher-resolution image, delivering better-looking games without requiring as much graphics hardware as youâ€™d need to render the higher-resolution image natively. Later additions have focused on improving ray-tracing performance and â€œframe generationâ€ technologies that boost frame rates by creating new AI-generated frames to insert between natively rendered frames. Generally speaking, Nvidiaâ€™s DLSS technologies have provided better image quality than AMDâ€™s FSR, but they have only been available on newer Nvidia hardwareâ€”the GeForce RTX 20-series or newer for most features, with frame-generation features locked to the RTX 40- and 50-series. FSRâ€™s results donâ€™t look as good, but they have benefited from running on just about anything, including older GPUs, Nvidia GPUs, and even integrated Intel and AMD GPUs. Today, AMD is trying to shift that dynamic witâ€¦

items.title: Operation Bluebird wants to relaunch â€œTwitter,â€ says Musk abandoned the name and logo
items.summary: â€œAbandonmentâ€ offers rare chance to reclaim one of techâ€™s most recognized brands.
items.body: A Virginia startup calling itself â€œOperation Bluebirdâ€ announced this week that it has filed a formal petition with the US Patent and Trademark Office, asking the federal agency to cancel X Corporationâ€™s trademarks of the words â€œTwitterâ€ and â€œtweetâ€ since X has allegedly abandoned them. â€œThe TWITTER and TWEET brands have been eradicated from X Corp.â€™s products, services, and marketing, effectively abandoning the storied brand, with no intention to resume use of the mark,â€ the petition states. â€œThe TWITTER bird was grounded.â€ If successful, two leaders of the group tell Ars, Operation Bluebird would launch a social network under the name Twitter.new , possibly as early as late next year. (Twitter.new has created a working prototype and is already inviting users to reserve handles.) Read full article Comments

items.title: Win hardware, collectibles, and more in the 2025 Ars Technica Charity Drive
items.summary: Help yourself to prizes by helping us raise money for good causes.
items.body: Itâ€™s once again that special time of year when we give you a chance to do well by doing good. Thatâ€™s rightâ€”itâ€™s the 2025 edition of our annual Charity Drive! Every year since 2007 , weâ€™ve encouraged readers to give to Penny Arcadeâ€™s Childâ€™s Play charity , which provides toys and games to kids being treated in hospitals around the world. In recent years, weâ€™ve added the Electronic Frontier Foundation to our charity push, aiding in their efforts to defend Internet freedom. This year, as always, weâ€™re providing some extra incentive for those donations by offering donors a chance to win pieces of our big pile of vendor-provided swag. We canâ€™t keep it, and we donâ€™t want it clogging up our offices, so itâ€™s now yours to win. This yearâ€™s swag pile is full of high-value geek goodies. We have over a dozen prizes valued at nearly $5,000 total , including gaming hardware and collectibles, apparel, and more. In 2023, Ars readers raised nearly $40,000 for charity , contributing to a total haul of more than $542,000 since 2007. We want to raise even more this year, and we can do it if readers dig deep. items.title: Over 250 people quarantined in South Carolina as measles outbreak rages
items.summary: 16 cases are linked to a church, which followed exposures at four schools last week.
items.body: A measles outbreak that began in South Carolina at the start of October is showing no signs of slowing as officials on Tuesday reported 27 new cases since Friday. Those cases bring the outbreak total to 111. The southern stateâ€™s outbreak now rivals outbreaks ongoing in Utah and Arizona , which have tallied 115 and 176 cases, respectively. The outbreaks are threatening to cost the country its measles elimination status , which was earned in 2000 after vaccination efforts stopped the virus from spreading continuously. If the current transmission of the virus isnâ€™t halted by January, the virus will have circulated for 12 consecutive months, marking it once again as an endemic disease in the US. In an update on Tuesday , South Carolinaâ€™s health department suggested the spread is far from over. Of the stateâ€™s 27 new cases, 16 were linked to exposure at a church, the Way of Truth Church in Inman. And amid the new cases, new exposures were identified at Inman Intermediate School. Thatâ€™s on top of exposures announced Friday at four other schools in the region, which led to well over 100 students being quarantined. Read full article Comments

items.title: Big Tech joins forces with Linux Foundation to standardize AI agents
items.summary: The Agentic AI Foundation launches to support MCP, AGENTS.md, and goose.
items.body: Big Tech has spent the past year telling us weâ€™re living in the era of AI agents, but most of what weâ€™ve been promised is still theoretical. As companies race to turn fantasy into reality, theyâ€™ve developed a collection of tools to guide the development of generative AI. A cadre of major players in the AI race, including Anthropic, Block, and OpenAI, has come together to promote interoperability with the newly formed Agentic AI Foundation (AAIF). This move elevates a handful of popular technologies and could make them a de facto standard for AI development going forward. The development path for agentic AI models is cloudy to say the least, but companies have invested so heavily in creating these systems that some tools have percolated to the surface. The AAIF, which is part of the nonprofit Linux Foundation, has been launched to govern the development of three key AI technologies: Model Context Protocol (MCP), goose, and AGENTS.md. MCP is probably the most well-known of the trio, having been open-sourced by Anthropic a year ago. The goal of MCP is to link AI agents to data sources in a standardized wayâ€”Anthropic (and now the AAIF) is fond of calling MCP a â€œ USB-C port for AI .â€ Râ€¦

items.title: Supreme Court appears likely to approve Trumpâ€™s firing of FTC Democrat
items.summary: Conservative justices seem ready to back Trump control of independent agencies.
items.body: The Supreme Courtâ€™s conservative justices appear ready to overturn a 90-year-old precedent that said the president cannot fire a Federal Trade Commission member without cause. A ruling for Trump would give him more power over the FTC and potentially other independent agencies such as the Federal Communications Commission. Former FTC Commissioner Rebecca Kelly Slaughter, a Democrat, sued Trump after he fired both Democrats from the commission in March. Slaughterâ€™s case rests largely on the 1935 ruling in Humphreyâ€™s Executor v. United States , in which the Supreme Court unanimously held that the president can only remove FTC commissioners for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. Chief Justice John Roberts said during yesterdayâ€™s oral arguments that Humphreyâ€™s Executor is a â€œdried huskâ€ despite being the â€œprimary authorityâ€ that Slaughterâ€™s legal team is relying on. Roberts said the courtâ€™s 2020 ruling in Seila Law made it â€œpretty clearâ€¦ that Humphreyâ€™s Executor is just a dried husk of whatever people used to think it was because, in the opinion itself, it described the powers of the agency it was talking about, and theyâ€™re vanishingly insignificant, have nothing â€¦

items.title: NASA astronauts will have their own droid when they go back to the Moon
items.summary: NASA crew will be the first astronauts to work with a robot on a celestial body other than Earth.
items.body: B-9 had Will Robinson. Twiki had Buck Rogers. And, of course, C-3PO and R2-D2 had Luke Skywalker. Now, in a scenario straight out of science fiction, MAPP will have whoever NASA names to the crew of the second Artemis mission to land on the moon. The space agency has selected Lunar Outpostâ€™s Mobile Autonomous Prospecting Platform, or MAPP, to become the first robotic rover to operate on the moon alongside astronauts . Although its tasks will be far simpler than those of the robots seen on TV and in the movies, the autonomous four-wheeled MAPP will help scientists learn more about the crewâ€™s surroundings. Science instruments on the rover will characterize the surface plasma and behavior of the dust in the lunar environment. â€œThe Apollo era taught us that the further humanity is from Earth, the more dependent we are on science to protect and sustain human life on other planets,â€ said Nicky Fox, NASAâ€™s associate administrator for science, in a statement. â€œBy deploying theseâ€¦ science instruments on the lunar surface, our proving ground, NASA is leading the world in the creation of humanityâ€™s interplanetary survival guide to ensure the health and safety of our spacecraft and human explâ€¦

items.title: Court: â€œBecause Trump said toâ€ may not be a legally valid defense
items.summary: The "arbitrary and capricious" standard strikes down another administration action.
items.body: On Monday, US District Court Judge Patti Saris vacated a Trump executive order that brought a halt to all offshore wind power development, as well as some projects on land. That order had called for the suspension of all permitting for wind power on federal land and waters pending a review of current practices. This led states and an organization representing wind power companies to sue, claiming among other things that the suspension was arbitrary and capricious. Over 10 months since the relevant government agencies were ordered to start a re-evaluation of the permitting process, testimony revealed that they had barely begun to develop the concept of a review. As such, the only reason they could offer in defense of the suspension consisted of Trumpâ€™s executive order and a Department of the Interior memo implementing it. â€œWhatever level of explanation is required when deviating from longstanding agency practice,â€ Judge Saris wrote, â€œthis is not it.â€ Lifting Trumpâ€™s suspension does not require the immediate approval of any wind projects. Instead, the relevant agencies are likely to continue following Trumpâ€™s wishes and slow-walking any leasing and licensing processes, which may forâ€¦

items.title: Google is reviving wearable gesture controls, but only for the Pixel Watch 4
items.summary: Google will let you select and dismiss with a gesture, but only on the newest watch.
items.body: Long ago, Googleâ€™s Android-powered wearables had hands-free navigation gestures. Those fell by the wayside as Google shredded its wearable strategy over and over, but gestures are back, baby. The Pixel Watch 4 is getting an update that adds several gestures, one of which is straight out of the Apple playbook . When the update hits devices, the Pixel Watch 4 will gain a double pinch gesture like the Apple Watch has. By tapping your thumb and forefinger together, you can answer or end calls, pause timers, and more. The watch will also prompt you at times when you can use the tap gesture to control things. In previous incarnations of Google-powered watches, a quick wrist turn gesture would scroll through lists. In the new gesture system, that motion dismisses whatâ€™s on the screen. For example, you can clear a notification from the screen or dismiss an incoming call. Pixel Watch 4 owners will also enjoy this one when the update arrives. Read full article Comments

items.title: Brazil weakens Amazon protections days after COP30
items.summary: Backed by powerful corporations, nations are giving public false choices: Environmental protection or economic growth.
items.body: Despite claims of environmental leadership and promises to preserve the Amazon rainforest ahead of COP30, Brazil is stripping away protections for the regionâ€™s vital ecosystems faster than workers dismantled the tents that housed the recent global climate summit in BelÃ©m. On Nov. 27, less than a week after COP30 ended, a powerful political bloc in Brazilâ€™s National Congress, representing agribusiness, and development interests, weakened safeguards for the Amazonâ€™s rivers, forests, and Indigenous communities. The rollback centered on provisions in an environmental licensing bill passed by the government a few months before COP30. The law began to take shape well before, during the Jair Bolsonaro presidency from 2019 to 2023. It reflected the deregulatory agenda of the rural caucus, the Frente Parlamentar da AgropecuÃ¡ria , which wielded significant power during his term and remains influential today. Read full article Comments

items.title: Pompeii construction site confirms recipe for Roman concrete
items.summary: Latest results from a recently discovered ancient Roman construction site confirm earlier findings.
items.body: Back in 2023, we reported on MIT scientistsâ€™ conclusion that the ancient Romans employed â€œhot mixingâ€ with quicklime, among other strategies, to make their famous concrete, giving the material self-healing functionality. The only snag was that this didnâ€™t match the recipe as described in historical texts. Now the same team is back with a fresh analysis of samples collected from a recently discovered site that confirms the Romans did indeed use hot mixing, according to a new paper published in the journal Nature Communications. As weâ€™ve reported previously , like todayâ€™s Portland cement (a basic ingredient of modern concrete), ancient Roman concrete was basically a mix of a semi-liquid mortar and aggregate. Portland cement is typically made by heating limestone and clay (as well as sandstone, ash, chalk, and iron) in a kiln. The resulting clinker is then ground into a fine powder with just a touch of added gypsum to achieve a smooth, flat surface. But the aggregate used to make Roman concrete was made up of fist-sized pieces of stone or bricks. In his treatise De architectura (circa 30 CE), the Roman architect and engineer Vitruvius wrote about how to build concrete walls for funerâ€¦

items.title: In a major new report, scientists build rationale for sending astronauts to Mars
items.summary: "Everyone is inspired by this because it's becoming real."
items.body: Sending astronauts to the red planet will be a decades-long activity and cost many billions of dollars. So why should NASA undertake such a bold mission? A new report published Tuesday , titled â€œA Science Strategy for the Human Exploration of Mars,â€ represents the answer from leading scientists and engineers in the United States: finding whether life exists, or once did, beyond Earth. â€œWeâ€™re searching for life on Mars,â€ said Dava Newman, a professor in the Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and co-chair of the committee that wrote the report, in an interview with Ars. â€œThe answer to the question â€˜are we alone â€˜ is always going to be â€˜maybe,â€™ unless it becomes yes.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Golang's big miss on memory arenas
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense
